/>
V.ii.2.E.1.a
.
Definition:  Congenital or Developmental Defects
Congenital
or
developmental defects
refer to normally static, structural, or inherent body abnormalities which are typically present at birth and are generally incapable of improvement or deterioration.  These include but are not limited to
vertebral anomalies such as block (fused) vertebrae
atrial septal defect
pectus excavatum
mental deficiency
absent, displaced, or supernumerary parts
personality disorder, and
undescended testicles.
Note
:  The presumption of soundness does not apply to congenital defects because such defects are not diseases or injuries within the meaning of the statutes governing the presumption.
References
:  For more information on
the prohibition of service connection (SC) for congenital or developmental defects, see
38 CFR 4.9
, and
38 CFR 3.303(c)
, and
the inapplicability of the presumption of soundness to congenital or developmental defects, see
Terry v. Principi
, 340 F.3d 1378, 1385-86 (Fed. Cir. 2003).
title: M21-1, Part V, Subpart ii, Chapter 2, Section E - Service Connection (SC) for Congenital, Developmental, or Hereditary Disorders
citation: Part V, Subpart ii, Chapter 2, Section E
